subject: contracts
tested_rule: Firm offer; battle of the forms; material alteration
fact_pattern: Quinn, a retailer, emails a signed offer to purchase 500 widgets from Jordan, a merchant, stating 'firm for 45 days.' Three days later, Jordan replies with a written acknowledgment adding an arbitration clause and a slightly different delivery schedule. Jordan ships conforming goods immediately; Quinn accepts and later sues to avoid arbitration after a dispute. The jurisdiction follows UCC Article 2. The timeline, roles, and governing standards are undisputed; the dispute turns on the precise doctrinal element.

options.A: The firm offer held the price; the additional arbitration term is a material alteration and does not enter without express assent.
options.B: All additional terms in a merchant confirmation automatically become part of the contract.
options.C: The reply was a counteroffer; shipment did not create a contract.
options.D: Arbitration is never a material alteration between merchants.

why_correct: Under §2-205 the signed firm offer is irrevocable; under §2-207, material alterations (e.g., arbitration) do not enter absent agreement.

why_others_wrong.C: A definite and seasonable expression + shipment forms a contract under §2-207(1).
why_others_wrong.D: Arbitration is typically treated as material absent course of dealing or assent.
